statement: This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, l=0, and r<2Â· 10^5. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem. You are given two integers l and r (lâ‰¤ r). Let n = r - l + 1. We will create two arrays a and b, both consisting of n integers. Initially, both a and b are equal to [l, l+1, ..., r]. You have to reorder the array a arbitrarily to maximize the following value:âˆ‘_{i=1}^n â‰¤ft (a_i\;|\;b_i \right ).Here, | denotes the bitwise OR operation. You also need to construct a possible way to reorder the array a.
input_specification: InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 10^4). The description of the test cases follows. The only line of each test case contains two integers l and r (0=lâ‰¤q r<2Â· 10^5) â€” the minimum and maximum elements in a.Let n = r - l + 1. It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2Â· 10^5.
output_specification: OutputFor each test case, print a single integer in the first line of output â€” the maximum value of âˆ‘\limits_{i=1}^n â‰¤ft (a_i\;|\;b_i \right ). Then, print n distinct integers a_1, a_2, ...,a_n in the second line â€” the array a after reordering.If there are multiple answers, you may print any of them.
note:
In the first test case, the reordered array
ð‘Ž
is
[3,2,1,0]
. The value of the expression is
(3|0)+(2|1)+(1|2)+(0|3)=3+3+3+3=12
. It can be proved that this is the maximum possible value of the expression.
In the second test case, the reordered array
ð‘Ž
is
[7,8,5,4,3,2,9,0,1,6]
. The value of the expression is
90
. It can be proved that this is the maximum possible value of the expression.
